FacilityName: NASA Glenn Research Center - Plum Brook Station

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



The purpose of this document is to provide the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) with the Risk Management Plan for storage and use of hydrogen for the purpose of aerospace propulsion testing and research at the NASA John H. Glenn Research Center (GRC) at Plum Brook Station (PBS).  The NASA GRC PBS conducts environmental testing of hardware and systems that are intended for space applications for NASA, the Department of Defense (DOD), and commercial aerospace industry.  This testing involves the storage and use of aerospace fluids, including hydrogen.  To meet future aerospace test requirements, NASA GRC PBS anticipates storage and use of hydrogen in amounts above the EPA threshold quantity of 10,000 lb.  At this time the worst-case analysis release modeling shows there are no public or environmental receptors impacted.  There have been no accidents pertaining to hydrogen at NASA GRC PBS in the past five years. 



A.     Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The NASA GRC PBS is committed to providing a safe place of employment by meeting or exceeding applicable health and safety requirements to assure personnel, community, environmental safety, and preservation of resources.  NASA GRC PBS has a history of conducting hazardous testing with liquid rocket propellants.  Designing, building, operating, and maintaining safe, reliable systems is the key to preventing accidental releases. 



The NASA GRC management system processes and procedures include key safety controls to properly contain and maintain the hazardous substances used and stored at PBS  The primary controls are engineering controls focused on the safe design, build up, and operation of systems. 



The NASA GRC achievement of ISO9001/AS9100 certification assures implementation of the Quality Management System (QMS) at the facility.  The QMS establishes a policy to provide accountability and ensure compliance with all applicable laws, regulations, and N

ASA GRC requirements.  The applicable NASA GRC requirements are Glenn Level Procedure (GLP)-QS-8715.1.6, Glenn Safety Manual - Chapter 6 Hydrogen located in the GRC Business Management System and NASA Program Requirement (NPR) 8715.3 General Safety Program Requirements.



The NASA GRC Pressure Systems Office, which is based on American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) code and other relevant national consensus standards, is of paramount importance in establishing, implementing, and verifying mechanical integrity of the systems that contain propellants. 



The NASA GRC PBS complies with emergency protocols developed by NASA GRC to be followed in the event of an accidental release of a hazardous substance.  The NASA GRC Emergency Management Plan provides directions for activities that eliminate or reduce the probability of disaster; prepare measures which protect life, the environment, and property; respond appropriately during emergencies; and establish a recovery system returning the facility to normal or improved operation following an emergency. 



The NASA GRC PBS efforts to prevent accidental release involves a review of lessons learned from the previous incidents within the Agency.  This includes a survey of hydrogen-related incidents in the NASA Mishap Information System (NMIS) and the NASA Lessons Learned Database.



B.    Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



Hazardous chemicals are essential in testing space systems at NASA GRC PBS.  The EPA regulates one of these chemicals that NASA GRC PBS possesses in an amount over the threshold quantity, hydrogen. This propellant is used in NASA, DOD, and commercial space systems.  The hydrogen is used for engine testing and to evaluate long term in-space storage and handling technologies and applications.  



At NASA GRC PBS, liquid hydrogen is stored in a 33,000-gallon storage dewar with a maximum allowable working pressure (MAWP) of 75 psig.  Commercial delivery is conducted into the storage

vessel with qualified facility personnel assisting the commercial driver to accomplish the transfer.  The storage vessel is protected by a relief valve and burst discs.  



Liquid Hydrogen is transferred from the storage vessel to the vacuum test chamber via a 3-inch stainless steel transfer line.  The operating tankage varies by test, but is typically located in the vacuum test chamber.  The facility is equipped with a 19,500-gallon vacuum jacketed dump tank.  It is utilized for rapid de-tanking of hydrogen in the event of an emergency. 



C.    General Accidental Release prevention Program and Chemical-Specific prevention



a.    The NASA GRC PBS Accidental Release Program

The NASA GRC PBS is strongly committed to safely conducting operations involving flammable substances, identifying and controlling to the greatest extent possible any hazards associated with these substances; and reducing any subsequent risk to the surrounding community and the environment. 



The NASA GRC Emergency Management Plan (EMP) outlines each NASA GRC organization's responsibility for following applicable emergency procedures contained in the plan and maintaining their organizational emergency procedures.  NASA GRC PBS follows the EMP which enables the emergency management activities to work effectively within the protocol of the National Response Framework (NRF) and the National Incident Management System (NIMS).  



b.    PBS Chemical-Prevention Steps

The Risk Management Plan (RMP) covered hydrogen process is also reviewed through the Pressure Systems Office to coordinate on fluid/material evaluations and component and system level analyses.  System configurations, review documentation, procedures, and maintenance records are controlled by a quality management system.  Employee training is managed through NASA's online training database as well as contractor training systems.  At the process level, the following are examples of additional risk mitigations employed: 

?    Pressure system c

ertification to NASA standards at defined interval (primarily based on degradation mechanisms, not to exceed 10 years).

?    Facility activation steps including cold shock conditioning of the system with nitrogen to ensure systems are leak tight. 

?    Safety and Readiness reviews, dry runs of approved procedures, and test specific training are performed to ensure personnel understand the task at hand, are aware of what to expect, and can recognize and respond to an upset condition when it occurs. 



D.    The Five-Year Accident History



The RMP as required by 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 68.190 of the rule, must contain an updated Five-Year Accident History which involves the reporting of significant accidental releases of RMP regulated substances from an RMP covered process in the five years prior to the submission of an initial or updated Risk Management Plan.  The Five-Year Accident History only pertains to releases from a covered process and involving a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.  The release must have caused at least one of the following:

?    On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (40 CFR 68.42(a)); or

?    Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (40 CFR 68.42(a)).



The EPA identifies in EPA 555-B-04-001, General Guidance on Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accident Prevention that if there has been a release of a regulated substance from a process where the regulated substance is held below its threshold quantity, then a facility does not need to report that release even if the release caused one of the listed impacts.  The NASA GRC PBS has not stored or used any quantity of hydrogen within in the last 5 years.  



There has not been an accidental release of the RMP regulated substances from the RMP covered processes at NASA GRC PBS in the last 5 years that has resulted in death, injury, or significant property damage on sit

e, nor any deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage offsite.  This determination was reached after reviewing the NASA Mishap Investigation and Reporting System (Close-Calls, Mishaps), Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Form 300 Log of Work-Related Injuries and Illnesses, and the Environmental Spill Reports



In accordance with 40 CFR 68.195(a), NASA GRC PBS will update the 2019 Risk Management Plan with any new accident history information for any accidental release meeting the Five-Year Accident History reporting criteria of 40 CFR 68.42. NASA GRC PBS will submit the release data with respect to that accident within six months of the release or by the time the RMP is updated under 40 CFR 68.190, whichever is earlier.



E.    Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios



Flammable dispersion modeling was performed to characterize a worst-case release scenario for the NASA GRC PBS covered process using RMP*eComp modeling software.  

                  

Modeling results identified that the worst case scenario is based on the largest potential capacity of the largest vessel (40 CFR 68.25(b)(1), taking into account administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity.  The facility storage vessel has a total liquid volume of 33,000 gallons of hydrogen (19,500 pounds).



The Worst-Case Release Scenario with the RMP*eComp gives the distance to the overpressure endpoint of 1 pound per square inch specified for hydrogen under the RMP Rule.  This is modeling a vapor cloud explosion with the wind speed of 1.5 meters per second (3.4 miles per hour) at an air temperature of 77 degrees F (25 degrees C).  



Due to the large buffer zone surrounding NASA GRC PBS, there are no public or environmental receptors within a 0.3-mile radius from the point of release to the flammable endpoint distance.  The nearest fence line is located 0.8 miles from the test facility.



F.    Emergency Response Program



The NASA

GRC Emergency Management Plan (EMP) is the basis for the PBS emergency response program.  This Plan provides direction to mitigate the effects of hazards, preserving life and minimizing damage to PBS operations and infrastructure.  This Plan directs response during emergencies, and establishes a recovery system in order to return the facility to normal operations after a major incident, such as a natural disaster or a technological accident.



The EMP establishes an Emergency Management Coordinator (EMC), who is responsible for managing the EMP and has the authority to implement EMP response, recovery, preparedness, and mitigation activities at NASA GRC PBS.  The NASA GRC PBS utilizes the Incident Command System (ICS) in the handling of emergencies and maintains Memoranda of Understanding (MOU) with local first responders as needed.  For more complex emergencies, the NASA GRC Incident Command will form a unified command with the local community emergency response entity.



Fire, medical, and chemical spills that exceed NASA GRC PBS local area capabilities to handle safely are examples of emergencies that will be handled using the ICS.  Emergencies of all types will be dealt with at the lowest level that is practical and safe.  When an incident is elevated to an emergency classification, there is a clear transition of authority to an Incident Commander once they arrive on the scene, and the local person in charge functions as the technical advisor.  The NASA GRC PBS follows an all-hazard approach and acknowledges that most responsibilities and functions performed during an emergency are not hazard specific.  This approach accounts for activities before, during, and after the emergency.  NASA GRC PBS addresses emergency management in four phases:

?    Mitigation activities that either reduce the probability of an emergency or minimize the adverse impact of an emergency. 

?    Preparedness activities ensure a high degree of readiness to provide swift and effective respo

nse and support during an emergency. 

?    Response measures taken during an incident that prevent loss of life and minimize damage to NASA GRC PBS and surrounding areas. 

?    Recovery actions taken to return systems to normal operations.



Appendix D.10, Emergency Support Function #10: Oil and Hazardous Materials Response of the NASA GRC EMP provides the policies and procedures for responding to emergency releases of a hazardous material and potential accidents that can have impact(s) on the environment.  If an emergency situation is progressing towards a neighboring community and has the potential to place them at risk, local authorities will be notified promptly by the EMC.  



Appendix D.13, Emergency Support Function #13: Public Safety and Security of the NASA GRC EMP established guidelines for the preservation of life, property, and law and order though the Office of Protective Services.  NASA GRC PBS is prepared to provide traffic control, maintain and monitor evacuation routes, and provide protective services functions.



Appendix D. 8, Emergency Support Function #8: Public Health and Medical Services of the NASA GRC EMP has the local fire and rescue departments and local emergency management agencies  provide public health and medical services during and after an emergency.  



NASA GRC PBS uses the Emergency Notification System (ENS) to notify employees.  The EMC conducts quarterly end-to-end testing using the ENS testing template.  



The NASA GRC EMP outlines the requirements for comprehensive training for all departments and personnel who support the emergency services at NASA GRC PBS.  All employees who work on-site have the potential of being exposed to hazardous materials must take the NASA GRC Hazard Communication training through the on-line training class accessible through System for Administration, Training, and Educational Resources at NASA (SATERN). 



NASA GRC Emergency Plans are updated as necessary based upon deficiencies identified by d

rills and exercises, changes in local management structure, and technological changes.  The EMP outlines annual tabletop and functional exercises and quarterly drills of the ENS.  The EMC maintains active liaisons with the local, state, and federal agencies that can provide emergency response to NASA GRC PBS.



Since NASA GRC PBS is a Program Level 1 process, the plan must be coordinated with the community and developed under the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  The Erie County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) receives the annual EPCRA Emergency and Hazardous Chemical Inventory Tier II Report from NASA GRC PBS.  In addition, at the request of local emergency planning or response officials, a facility must provide any information necessary for developing and implementing the community plan.



The NASA GRC PBS recognizes the need for public awareness where hazardous chemicals are concerned.  Representatives from NASA GRC PBS participate in the Erie County LEPC.  They brief the committee on what chemicals are located on site, what processes they are involved in, and what safety precautions are taken to ensure the safety of employees as well as the public. 



The 40 CFR 68.195(b) identifies that within one month of any change in the RMP emergency contact information required under ?68.160(b)(6), NASA GRC PBS shall submit a correction of that information.  40 The CFR 68.160(b)(6) identifies that the RMP must include the name, title, telephone number, 24-hour telephone number, and the e-mail address (if an e-mail address exists) of the emergency contact.  The NASA GRC PBS will update emergency contact information identified in the RMP for the required contact information.



G.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety



The NASA GRC PBS will implement a Process Safety Management (PSM) Program in advance of exceeding the threshold quantity of liquid hydrogen in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous

Chemicals.  Through the 14 elements of PSM, NASA GRC PBS will strive to continuously improve safety of personnel, the public and the environment.  The following section briefly describes the PSM elements that will be in place at NASA GRC PBS.



?    Process Safety Information - Detailed engineering drawings of the covered process and adjacent systems, chemical safety, operating parameters, and equipment safety information is compiled and readily available to operators and personnel involved in the operation and maintenance of the hydrogen system.  The Process Safety Information enables employees to perform a Process Hazards Analysis for the covered process.  



?    Process Hazard Analysis - A comprehensive study is performed to ensure hazards associated with the processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  The methodology used to carry out the analysis is a What-If/Checklist to determine and evaluate the hazards of the process being analyzed.  The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated every 5 years after the initial analysis. 



?    Operating Procedures - For the purposes of safely conducting activities within the PSM covered processes, PBS maintains written operating procedures.  While the PSM procedures are active, they are reviewed annually.  Procedures are readily accessible to employees who work oin or maintain the process. These procedures provide clear instruction for safely conducting activities which utilize the covered processes and are consistent with the Process Safety Information and the Process Hazards Analysis.



?    Training - Personnel whose job tasks are related to the operation and maintenance of the Hydrogen System are given training on safe operation of the facility and safe use of the highly hazardous chemical.  Employees may be involved through self-managed learning, coaching and mentoring new employees, presenting training as subject matter experts,

or on-the-job training.  



?    Mechanical Integrity - NASA guidelines are followed for maintaining the mechanical integrity of the process equipment to help prevent equipment failures that could endanger personnel, public and the environment.  The mechanical integrity program includes inspection, testing and re-certification of the storage and transfer systems to help identify equipment deterioration, malfunction and damage.  



?    Management of Change - Proposed changes to the equipment and operating procedures are evaluated and approved to ensure the change does not adversely affect the safety of operations.  Active participation of the affected employees is essential to the success of a Management of Change program. Personnel whose job task will be affected are informed of and trained on changes made to a process and on the impacts of the changes prior to startup of the process.  



?    Pre-Startup Review - A safety review of a new or modified process is performed in accordance with NASA guidelines before a system is brought into service.  This review confirms the design and construction of equipment is in accordance with the design specifications; safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place; employee training has been completed; and a process hazard analysis has been performed.  



?    Compliance Audit - Compliance audits of the hydrogen system will be conducted by NASA GRC on a 3-year basis.  Audit results will be documented and recommendations will be resolved following a developed schedule.   



?    Incident Investigation - NASA GRC PBS will promptly investigate all incidents that have resulted in or could reasonable have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public or the environment so similar accidents can be prevented.  



?    Employee Participation - Process safety and accident prevention is a team effort.  Prior to PSM implementation, NASA GRC PBS will develop an employee participation plan that outlines employee's involve

ment in the development and maintenance of the documentation associated with the PSM elements.  Employees will have access to all process documentation, records and information created as part of the facility's implementation of PSM.  



?    Hot work Permits - NASA GRC has a Hot Work Permit process that is used for hot work operations near the PSM covered process.  Employees ensure fire prevention and protection requirements have been implemented prior to starting the hot work.   

 

?    Contractors - Contractors and subcontractors are required to conduct work in a safe manner while working at NASA GRC PBS.  This begins with submittal of a Hazard and Safety Plan prior to initiating work on site.  Contractors are informed of hazards, emergency procedures and process safety requirements.
